channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: More storms ahead, warn forecasters
item.description: Forecasters warn of a fresh burst of heavy rain and wind across the UK on Monday, as some homes hit by Christmas storms are told they face more days without power.

item.title: Soldier killed in Afghanistan named
item.description: A British soldier killed in Afghanistan two days before Christmas is named as Captain Richard Holloway, 29, of The Royal Engineers.

item.title: Mother and daughter hurt in blast
item.description: A British woman and her eight-year-old daughter are among several people who have suffered burns after an explosion at a poolside bar on the Spanish resort island of Tenerife.

item.title: Cairo campus torched amid protest
item.description: A student dies in Cairo as supporters of Egypt's banned Muslim Brotherhood clash with police and university buildings are set on fire.

item.title: No agreement yet in Haass NI talks
item.description: Talks aimed at solving some of Northern Ireland's most contentious issues end on Saturday without agreement.

item.title: Ban smacking, children's tsar urges
item.description: Parents should be banned from smacking their children, the Children's Commissioner for England, Maggie Atkinson, says in a newspaper interview.

item.title: S Sudan rebel youths in 'war march'
item.description: Thousands of youths loyal to South Sudanese rebel leader Riek Machar are marching on the strategic town of Bor, according to government sources.

item.title: Woman charged with man's fire death
item.description: A woman is charged with murder after a man died in a house fire on Christmas Day.

item.title: Strike on Syria market 'kills 21'
item.description: A Syrian government airstrike on a crowded market in the northern city of Aleppo has killed at least 20 people, activists say.

item.title: Ice hampers Antarctic ship rescue
item.description: A scientific mission ship, trapped in dense pack ice off East Antarctica, is still awaiting rescue after a Chinese icebreaker failed to reach it.

item.title: FA investigates Anelka celebration
item.description: France's Sport Minister accuses Nicolas Anelka of a "disgusting" goal celebration during West Brom's 3-3 draw at West Ham.

item.title: Baby for Robin Hood and Maid Marian
item.description: Nottingham's official Robin Hood and Maid Marian announce the birth of a girl, Scarlett Louise.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Magnetic man' breaks spoon record
item.description: Georgian Etibar Elchev has broken his own record for carrying metal spoons on his chest and back.

item.title: Manchester City 1-0 Crystal Palace
item.description: Manchester City move to the top of the Premier League for the first time this season after a win over Crystal Palace.

item.title: England's worst display - Vaughan
item.description: Former captain Michael Vaughan says the players must take the blame for England's latest batting collapse down under.

item.title: Hull City 6-0 Fulham
item.description: Steve Bruce's Hull score six second-half goals as they move seven points clear of 18th-placed Fulham.

item.title: Mountainous wins Welsh National
item.description: Mountainous beats Hawkes Bay and Tidal Bay in a tight three-way finish to win the Welsh National at Chepstow.

item.title: 'Lyon takes on the big beasts and chews them up'
item.description: England's dizzy decline on the third day at the MCG may be the nadir of an unhappy tour, says chief sports writer Tom Fordyce

item.title: Japan close to escaping deflation
item.description: Japanese consumer prices rise at the fastest pace in five years, showing government policies to end its deflation problem may be taking effect.

item.title: VIDEO: Managing nation's energy supplies
item.description: The chief executive of National Grid says with the world consuming more energy, most of the pressure on prices is up.

item.title: Party leaders unite for Syria appeal
item.description: David Cameron, Ed Miliband and Nick Clegg issue a rare joint statement backing a Â£4bn United Nations appeal on behalf of Syrian refugees.

item.title: AUDIO: 'UKIP to completely change UK politics'
item.description: The UK Independence Party will "completely change British politics" if it wins next year's European elections, according to the party's head of policy.

item.title: Trust apologises over DNA failings
item.description: An NHS Trust apologises for "inexcusable failings" after complaints a sexual assault referral centre in London did not send samples for DNA testing.

item.title: VIDEO: Battle against polio - in 60 seconds
item.description: BBC News outlines the global battle against polio - in 60 seconds.

item.title: Extra support to streamline adoption
item.description: More information is to be made available online to speed up the process of finding new homes for children waiting for adoption

item.title: AUDIO: Universities accepting lower grades
item.description: Leading universities are accepting more students with lower grades, a UCAS report suggests.

item.title: Days of the 'bank job' are numbered
item.description: Robberies on British bank branches have dropped by 90% in the past decade, figures suggest, citing better technology for the decline.

item.title: VIDEO: Fall of the machines at 'robot Olympics'
item.description: The BBC attended the robot competition run by the Pentagon's research unit and saw the gap between today's technology facts and the science fiction of the future.

item.title: Ocean currents may solve eel mystery
item.description: Scientists say that a new model of wind-driven ocean currents may explain large fluctuations in the numbers of European eels.

item.title: VIDEO: Mexico City's smog-capture building
item.description: New technology is being used in a building in Mexico City that its designers say transforms pollutants into harmless chemicals.

item.title: TV hit Broadchurch tops critics' poll
item.description: Broadchurch, starring David Tennant, has been named 2013's best television programme in an annual poll by Radio Times critics.

item.title: VIDEO: Britney begins Las Vegas residency
item.description: Singer Britney Spears begins her two-year residency at the Las Vegas Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino.

item.title: The rise of the 'extreme commuter'
item.description: Most people hate commuting, a modern-day necessary evil. So why would anyone choose to build a lengthy commute into their lifestyle, asks Karen Gregor.

item.title: The forgotten photojournalist killed in action
item.description: In 1937 Gerda Taro became the first female war photographer to die on the front line, killed at the age of 26.

item.title: PM 'harangued' by flood victims - the papers
item.description: The image of David Cameron being berated by angry householders left without power for days leads several of Saturday's newspapers.

item.title: Police 'confident' body is hiker's
item.description: Rescuers in New Zealand are "confident" the body recovered at the bottom of a 300ft (100m) cliff is that of a missing British hiker.

item.title: Man responsible for house shootings
item.description: A man found dead at a house in Nottinghamshire was responsible for shooting a woman and himself, according to police.

item.title: Call to end ambulance speed tickets
item.description: The Tories call for action after it emerges hundreds of speeding tickets were issued to the Scottish Ambulance Service last year.

item.title: Power restored but more storms ahead
item.description: Engineers restore power to homes cut off by the stormy weather while forecasters warn of more heavy rain and high winds to come.

item.title: Ecstasy warning after man's death
item.description: Police in Northern Ireland issue a warning over a type of yellow ecstasy known as "speckled Rolex" after one man died and four others were hospitalised.

item.title: Thatcher pressed on plastic bullets
item.description: Previously unreleased state papers from 1983 reveal an exchange of letters between Margaret Thatcher and an English surgeon about the use of plastic bullets in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Power still cut after 109mph gales
item.description: Engineers work to reconnect power to around 1,000 properties in north Wales still cut off following the Boxing Day storm.

item.title: Appeal after man found unconscious
item.description: Police cordon off an area at Sophia Gardens in Cardiff after a man is found unconscious.

item.title: Chadians evacuated from CAR conflict
item.description: More Chadians flee the Central African Republic after being caught in the fighting there, joining thousands who have left in the past week.

item.title: Mali ex-leader in high treason probe
item.description: Mali says it will investigate ousted leader Amadou Toumani Toure for high treason, accusing him of failing to stop an Islamist insurgency.

item.title: Deadly fire engulfs India train
item.description: At least 26 people, including two children, die after a fire breaks out on a train in Andhra Pradesh, India - with many trapped inside the inferno.

item.title: Mass China poll bribe resignations
item.description: More than 500 municipal lawmakers in one Chinese province have stood down following an electoral fraud scandal, according to state media.

item.title: Turkey's PM Erdogan vows to fight on
item.description: Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan says he will not step down amid corruption allegations that have forced the resignations of three ministers.

item.title: Croatia charges over drugs bribes
item.description: Croatian officials charge a pharmaceutical company and 364 people - most of them reportedly doctors - for allegedly rigging the drugs market.

item.title: Brazil jail fights kill 59 in 2013
item.description: At least 59 inmates have been killed in a single northern Brazilian prison this year, according to a judicial report detailing torture and sexual violence.

item.title: Brazil indigenous reserve attacked
item.description: Residents of a remote town in Brazil's Amazonas state attack an indigenous reserve, hours after members of a nearby tribe sought refuge at an army base.

item.title: Iraq troops arrest MP in deadly raid
item.description: Iraqi forces have arrested an MP, killing his brother and five of his guards who had opened fire on the officers, police say.

item.title: Bahrain opposition leader 'arrested'
item.description: The main Shia opposition movement in Bahrain, al-Wefaq, says its leader, Sheikh Ali Salman, has been arrested.

item.title: Newtown shooting report 'painful'
item.description: US police release thousands of documents tied to their investigation into a Connecticut school shooting, during which 26 people died.

item.title: Libya 'frees' US military personnel
item.description: The Libyan authorities have released four American military personnel detained on Friday, US officials say.

item.title: In pictures: Christmas around the world
item.description: Images of Christmas celebrations

item.title: Day in pictures: 23 December 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 23 December

item.title: Year in pictures 2013
item.description: Striking news images from around the world

item.title: In pictures: The 2013 Strictly final
item.description: Abbey Clancy wins Strictly Come Dancing

item.title: In pictures: Shoppers hit the sales
item.description: Shoppers queue to bag a bargain as stores across the UK open for the Boxing Day sales.

item.title: In pictures: Lockerbie anniversary
item.description: 25th anniversary of the bombing of Pan Am 103

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 December 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 December

item.title: In pictures: Apollo Theatre ceiling collapse
item.description: London's Apollo Theatre where ceiling collapsed

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: David Cameron welcomes the "encouraging" fall in unemployment.

item.title: VIDEO: Antarctic ship rescue hampered by ice
item.description: A Chinese icebreaker vessel has failed to reach a scientific ship trapped in pack ice off East Antarctica.

item.title: VIDEO: South Sudan truce offer 'genuine'
item.description: The offer of a truce between government forces and rebels is "genuine", the country's vice president has said.

item.title: VIDEO: Haass in Belfast for NI talks
item.description: Former US diplomat Richard Haass is in Belfast to try and revitalise talks aimed at solving some of Northern Ireland's most contentious issues.

item.title: VIDEO: Cairo campus ablaze amid protests
item.description: Cairo's al-Azhar University was set on fire and one person killed as supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood clashed with security forces.

item.title: VIDEO: Delhi swears in new chief minister
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of a new anti-corruption party in India, is sworn in as Delhi's chief minister at the city's Ramlila Ground.

item.title: VIDEO: Deadly fire engulfs India train
item.description: At least 26 people, including two children, have died after a fire broke out on a train in southern India, media reports say.

item.title: VIDEO: Starmer: 'Significant shift' needed
item.description: Former chief prosecutor, Keir Starmer, is to lead a review for the Labour Party on the way rape victims and abused children are treated in court.

item.title: VIDEO: Safe standing 'common sense'
item.description: Standing could make a permanent return at all levels of the Football League after its 72 clubs were sent a document canvassing their opinion on the issue.

item.title: In pictures: Best space images of 2013
item.description: Out of this world - the best space images of 2013

item.title: England in a mess after more batting woe
item.description: England in a mess after more batting woe

item.title: 10 extraordinary sacred sites around Britain
item.description: 10 sites that were sacred to ancient Britons

item.title: Two cheers for human rights
item.description: Are there times when human rights are not the solution?

item.title: The food co-op where shoppers are happy to work
item.description: The grocery store where university professors stock vegetables

item.title: Losing glasses puts Somalia in focus
item.description: The pair of glasses lost on the battlefield - and returned

item.title: Audio slideshow: The ends of the line in Shanghai
item.description: Images from the ends of Shanghai's metro lines

item.title: How animals help us understand disease
item.description: The creatures helping us understand human disease

item.title: Lebanon assassination targets potential prime minister
item.description: Lebanon assassination targeted potential PM, Kim Ghattas says

item.title: Was 2013 the NHS's annus horriblis?
item.description: Nick Triggle on whether 2013 was NHS's annus horriblis

item.title: Europe's moments of 2013
item.description: Gavin Hewitt on Merkel, Pope, migrants and Berlusconi
